segment.source: Use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager to create and update your Enterprise Mode site list for devices running Windows 10.
segment.target: Use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager to create and update your Enterprise Mode site list for devices running Windows 10.

segment.source: Enterprise Mode schema v.2 guidance (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)
segment.target: Enterprise Mode schema v.2 guidance (Internet Explorer 11 for IT Pros)

segment.source: Use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager to create and update your site list for devices running Windows 7, Windows 8.1, and Windows 10, using the version 2.0 (v.2) of the Enterprise Mode schema.
segment.target: Use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager to create and update your site list for devices running Windows 7, Windows 8.1, and Windows 10, using the version 2.0 (v.2) of the Enterprise Mode schema.

segment.source: If you don't want to use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager, you also have the option to update your XML schema using Notepad, or any other XML-editing app.
segment.target: If you don't want to use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager, you also have the option to update your XML schema using Notepad, or any other XML-editing app.

segment.source: If you're running Windows 7 or Windows 8.1 and you've been using the version 1.0 (v.1) of the schema, you can continue to do so, but you won't get the benefits that come with the updated schema.
segment.target: If you're running Windows 7 or Windows 8.1 and you've been using the version 1.0 (v.1) of the schema, you can continue to do so, but you won't get the benefits that come with the updated schema.

segment.source: For info about the v.1 schema, see Enterprise Mode schema v.1 guidance.
segment.target: For info about the v.1 schema, see Enterprise Mode schema v.1 guidance.

segment.source: Because of the schema changes, you can't combine the old version (v.1) with the new version (v.2) of the schema.
segment.target: Because of the schema changes, you can't combine the old version (v.1) with the new version (v.2) of the schema.

segment.source: If you look at your XML file, you can tell which version you're using by:
segment.target: If you look at your XML file, you can tell which version you're using by:

segment.source: If your schema root node includes this key, you're using the v.1 version of the schema.
segment.target: If your schema root node includes this key, you're using the v.1 version of the schema.

segment.source: If your schema root node includes this key, you're using the v.2 version of the schema.
segment.target: If your schema root node includes this key, you're using the v.2 version of the schema.

segment.source: You can continue to use the v.1 version of the schema on Windows 10, but you won't have the benefits of the new v.2 version schema updates and new features.
segment.target: You can continue to use the v.1 version of the schema on Windows 10, but you won't have the benefits of the new v.2 version schema updates and new features.

segment.source: Additionally, if you save the v.1 version of the schema in the new Enterprise Mode Site List Manager for Windows 10, it will automatically update the file to use the v.2 version of the schema.
segment.target: Additionally, if you save the v.1 version of the schema in the new Enterprise Mode Site List Manager for Windows 10, it will automatically update the file to use the v.2 version of the schema.

segment.source: The following is an example of the v.2 version of the Enterprise Mode schema.
segment.target: The following is an example of the v.2 version of the Enterprise Mode schema.

segment.source: Make sure that you don't specify a protocol when adding your URLs.
segment.target: Make sure that you don't specify a protocol when adding your URLs.

segment.source: Using a URL like , automatically applies to both http://contoso.com and https://contoso.com.
segment.target: Using a URL like , automatically applies to both http://contoso.com and https://contoso.com.

segment.source: This table includes the elements used by the v.2 version of the Enterprise Mode schema.
segment.target: This table includes the elements used by the v.2 version of the Enterprise Mode schema.

segment.source: A new root node with this text is using the updated v.2 version of the schema.
segment.target: A new root node with this text is using the updated v.2 version of the schema.

segment.source: A unique entry added for each site you want to put on the Enterprise Mode site list.
segment.target: A unique entry added for each site you want to put on the Enterprise Mode site list.

segment.source: The first site element will overrule any additional site elements that use the same value for the url element.
segment.target: The first site element will overrule any additional site elements that use the same value for the url element.

segment.source: You can also use the self-closing version, url="contoso.com" /, which also sets:
segment.target: You can also use the self-closing version, url="contoso.com" /, which also sets:

segment.source: A child element that controls what compatibility setting is used for specific sites or domains.
segment.target: A child element that controls what compatibility setting is used for specific sites or domains.

segment.source: This element is only supported in IE11.
segment.target: This element is only supported in IE11.

segment.source: Loads the site in IE8 Enterprise Mode.
segment.target: Loads the site in IE8 Enterprise Mode.

segment.source: This element is required for sites included in the EmIE section of the v.1 schema and is needed to load in IE8 Enterprise Mode.
segment.target: This element is required for sites included in the EmIE section of the v.1 schema and is needed to load in IE8 Enterprise Mode.

segment.source: Loads the site in IE7 Enterprise Mode.
segment.target: Loads the site in IE7 Enterprise Mode.

segment.source: This element is required for sites included in the EmIE section of the v.1 schema and is needed to load in IE7 Enterprise Mode.
segment.target: This element is required for sites included in the EmIE section of the v.1 schema and is needed to load in IE7 Enterprise Mode.

segment.source: This tag replaces the combination of the attribute and the list of sites specified in the EmIE section of the v.1 version of the schema.
segment.target: This tag replaces the combination of the attribute and the list of sites specified in the EmIE section of the v.1 version of the schema.

segment.source: Where [x] is the document mode number into which the site loads.
segment.target: Where [x] is the document mode number into which the site loads.

segment.source: Loads the site using the default compatibility mode for the page.
segment.target: Loads the site using the default compatibility mode for the page.

segment.source: In this situation, X-UA-compatible meta tags or HTTP headers are honored.
segment.target: In this situation, X-UA-compatible meta tags or HTTP headers are honored.

segment.source: A child element that controls what browser is used for sites.
segment.target: A child element that controls what browser is used for sites.

segment.source: This element supports the Open in IE11 or Open in Microsoft Edge experiences, for devices running Windows 10.
segment.target: This element supports the Open in IE11 or Open in Microsoft Edge experiences, for devices running Windows 10.

segment.source: Opens the site in IE11, regardless of which browser is opened by the employee.
segment.target: Opens the site in IE11, regardless of which browser is opened by the employee.

segment.source: Opens the site in Microsoft Edge, regardless of which browser is opened by the employee.
segment.target: Opens the site in Microsoft Edge, regardless of which browser is opened by the employee.

segment.source: Opens in whatever browser the employee chooses.
segment.target: Opens in whatever browser the employee chooses.

segment.source: The url attribute, as part of the site element in the v.2 version of the schema, replaces the domain element from the v.1 version of the schema.
segment.target: The url attribute, as part of the site element in the v.2 version of the schema, replaces the domain element from the v.1 version of the schema.

segment.source: Specifies the version of the Enterprise Mode Site List.
segment.target: Specifies the version of the Enterprise Mode Site List.

segment.source: This attribute is supported for the site-list element.
segment.target: This attribute is supported for the site-list element.

segment.source: Specifies the URL (and port number using standard port conventions) to which the child elements apply.
segment.target: Specifies the URL (and port number using standard port conventions) to which the child elements apply.

segment.source: The URL can be a domain, sub-domain, or any path URL.
segment.target: The URL can be a domain, sub-domain, or any path URL.

segment.source: Make sure that you don't specify a protocol.
segment.target: Make sure that you don't specify a protocol.

segment.source: Using site url="contoso.com" applies to both http://contoso.com and https://contoso.com.
segment.target: Using site url="contoso.com" applies to both http://contoso.com and https://contoso.com.

segment.source: In this example, going to http://contoso.com:8080 using Microsoft Edge, causes the site to open in IE11 and load in IE8 Enterprise Mode.
segment.target: In this example, going to http://contoso.com:8080 using Microsoft Edge, causes the site to open in IE11 and load in IE8 Enterprise Mode.

segment.source: These v.1 version schema attributes have been deprecated in the v.2 version of the schema:
segment.target: These v.1 version schema attributes have been deprecated in the v.2 version of the schema:

segment.source: While the old, replaced attributes aren't supported in the v.2 version of the schema, they'll continue to work in the v.1 version of the schema.
segment.target: While the old, replaced attributes aren't supported in the v.2 version of the schema, they'll continue to work in the v.1 version of the schema.

segment.source: If, however, you're using the v.2 version of the schema and these attributes are still there, the v.2 version schema takes precedence.
segment.target: If, however, you're using the v.2 version of the schema and these attributes are still there, the v.2 version schema takes precedence.

segment.source: We don’t recommend combining the two schemas, and instead recommend that you move to the v.2 version of the schema to take advantage of the new features.
segment.target: We don’t recommend combining the two schemas, and instead recommend that you move to the v.2 version of the schema to take advantage of the new features.

segment.source: Saving your v.1 version of the file using the new Enterprise Mode Site List Manager (schema v.2) automatically updates the XML to the new v.2 version of the schema.
segment.target: Saving your v.1 version of the file using the new Enterprise Mode Site List Manager (schema v.2) automatically updates the XML to the new v.2 version of the schema.

segment.source: What not to include in your schema
segment.target: What not to include in your schema

segment.source: We recommend that you not add any of the following items to your schema because they can make your compatibility list behave in unexpected ways:
segment.target: We recommend that you not add any of the following items to your schema because they can make your compatibility list behave in unexpected ways:

segment.source: For example, http://, https://, or custom protocols.
segment.target: For example, http://, https://, or custom protocols.

segment.source: Don’t use query strings, ampersands break parsing.
segment.target: Don’t use query strings, ampersands break parsing.

segment.source: Use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager
segment.target: Use the Enterprise Mode Site List Manager
